cards.name: Orc General
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice another Orc or Goblin: Other Orc creatures get +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Your army must fear you more than the enemy. Only then will you triumph." —Malga Phlegmtooth
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice one Orc or Goblin to give all Orcs +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Sisters of the Flame
cards.text: {T}: Add {R}.
cards.flavor: We are many wicks sharing a common tallow; we feed the skies with the ashes of our prey.
cards.originalText: {T}: Add {R} to your mana pool. This ability is played as an interrupt.

cards.name: Angry Mob
cards.text:
Trample
As long as it's your turn, Angry Mob's power and toughness are each equal to 2 plus the number of Swamps your opponents control. As long as it's not your turn, Angry Mob's power and toughness are each 2.
cards.originalText:
Trample
During your turn, the *s below are both equal to the total number of swamps all opponents control. During any other player's turn, * equals 0.

cards.name: Blood of the Martyr
cards.text: Until end of turn, if damage would be dealt to any creature, you may have that damage dealt to you instead.
cards.flavor: The willow knows what the storm does not: that the power to endure harm outlives the power to inflict it.
cards.originalText: For the remainder of the turn, you may redirect damage done to any number of creatures to yourself instead.

cards.name: Brainwash
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack unless its controller pays {3}.
cards.flavor: "They're not your friends; they despise you. I'm the only one you can count on. Trust me."

rulings.text: This ability is paid for during the declare attackers step of the combat phase.
If there are multiple combat phases during the turn, the attack cost must be paid each time if you want to attack with the creature.
Paying this cost is not an instant or any other kind of ability, it is an additional cost on the declaration of the attacker.

cards.originalText: Target creature may not attack unless its controller pays {3} in addition to any other costs required for the creature to attack.

cards.name: Cleansing
cards.text: For each land, destroy that land unless any player pays 1 life.
cards.originalText: All land is destroyed. Players may prevent Cleansing from destroying specific lands by paying 1 life for each land they wish to protect. Effects that prevent or redirect damage may not be used to counter this loss of life.

cards.name: Dust to Dust
cards.text: Exile two target artifacts.
cards.flavor: Tervish never noticed that the amulet had vanished. It had disappeared not only from his possession, but from his memory as well.

rulings.text: If one target is removed or becomes invalid after declaration, the other target is still affected.

cards.originalText: Removes two target artifacts from the game.

cards.name: Exorcist
cards.text: {1}{W}, {T}: Destroy target black creature.
cards.flavor: Though they often bore little greater charm than the demons they battled, exorcists were always welcome in Scarwood.
cards.originalText: {1}{W}, {T}: Target black creature is destroyed.

cards.name: Fasting
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a hunger counter on Fasting. Then destroy Fasting if it has five or more hunger counters on it.
If you would begin your draw step, you may skip that step instead. If you do, you gain 2 life.
When you draw a card, destroy Fasting.

rulings.text: When you resolve the beginning-of-upkeep triggered ability, you first put a hunger counter on Fasting, then you check how many hunger counters it has. If there are five or more, Fasting is destroyed.
You choose whether or not to skip your draw step as that step begins. This ability is now separate from the beginning-of-upkeep triggered ability.

cards.originalText: You may choose to skip your draw phase; if you do so, you gain 2 life. If you draw a card for any reason, Fasting is destroyed. During your upkeep, put a hunger counter on Fasting. When Fasting has five hunger counters on it, it is destroyed.

cards.name: Festival
cards.text:
Cast this spell only during an opponent's upkeep.
Creatures can't attack this turn.
cards.flavor: Only after the townsfolk had drawn us into their merry celebration did we discover that their holiday rituals held a deeper purpose.
cards.originalText: Opponent may not declare an attack this turn. Play during opponent's upkeep phase.

cards.name: Fire and Brimstone
cards.text: Fire and Brimstone deals 4 damage to target player who attacked this turn and 4 damage to you.
cards.originalText: Fire and Brimstone does 4 damage to target player and 4 damage to you. Can only be used during a turn in which target player has declared an attack.

cards.name: Holy Light
cards.text: Nonwhite creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Bathed in hallowed light, the infidels looked upon the impurities of their souls and despaired." —The Book of Tal
cards.originalText: All non-white creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Knights of Thorn
cards.text: Protection from red; banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor: "With a great cry, the Goblin host broke and ran as the first wave of Knights penetrated its ranks." —Tivadar of Thorn, History of the Goblin Wars

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Protection from red, banding

cards.name: Martyr's Cry
cards.text: Exile all white creatures. For each creature exiled this way, its controller draws a card.
cards.flavor: "It is only fitting that one such as I should die in pursuit of knowledge." —Vervamon the Elder

rulings.text: Only affects creatures on the battlefield, not ones in hands or graveyards.

cards.originalText: All white creatures are removed from the game. Players must draw one card for each white creature they control that is lost in this manner.

cards.name: Miracle Worker
cards.text: {T}: Destroy target Aura attached to a creature you control.
cards.flavor: "Those blessed hands could bring surcease to even the most tainted soul." —Sister Betje, Miracles of the Saints
cards.originalText: {T}: Destroy target enchantment card on a creature you control.

cards.name: Morale
cards.text: Attacking creatures get +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "After Lacjsi's speech, the Knights grew determined to crush their ancient enemies clan by clan." —Tivadar of Thorn, History of the Goblin Wars
cards.originalText: All attacking creatures gain +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Pikemen
cards.text: First strike; banding (Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.)
cards.flavor: "As the cavalry bore down, we faced them with swords drawn and pikes hidden in the grass at our feet. 'Don't lift your pikes 'til I give the word,' I said." —Maeveen O'Donagh, Memoirs of a Soldier

rulings.text: If a creature with banding attacks, it can team up with any number of other attacking creatures with banding (and up to one nonbanding creature) and attack as a unit called a "band." The band can be blocked by any creature that could block a single creature in the band. Blocking any creature in a band blocks the entire band. If a creature with banding is blocked, the attacking player chooses how the blockers' damage is assigned.
A maximum of one nonbanding creature can join an attacking band no matter how many creatures with banding are in it.
Creatures in the same band must all attack the same player or planeswalker.
If a creature in combat has banding, its controller assigns damage for creatures blocking or blocked by it. That player can ignore the damage assignment order when making this assignment.

cards.originalText: Banding, first strike

cards.name: Preacher
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Preacher during your untap step.
{T}: For as long as Preacher remains tapped, gain control of target creature of an opponent's choice they control.

rulings.text: The target of the ability is a creature the chosen opponent controls. As the ability resolves, if the target isn't a creature controlled by the chosen opponent, the ability won't resolve. If the ability's target is changed somehow, the new target must be a creature controlled by the chosen opponent.

Whether Preacher is tapped is checked continually, starting when the ability is activated. If, before the ability resolves, there's any point at which Preacher is untapped, the ability has no effect — even if Preacher is tapped again by the time the ability resolves.
When you activate the ability, you choose an opponent, then that opponent chooses the target.

cards.originalText: {T}: Gain control of one of opponent's creatures. Opponent chooses which target creature you control. If Preacher becomes untapped, you lose control of this creature; you may choose not to untap Preacher as normal during your untap phase. You also lose control of the creature if Preacher leaves play or at end of game.

cards.name: Squire
cards.flavor: "Of twenty yeer of age he was, I gesse. Of his stature he was of even lengthe. And wonderly deliver, and greete of strengthe." —Geoffrey Chaucer, The Canterbury Tales

cards.name: Tivadar's Crusade
cards.text: Destroy all Goblins.
cards.originalText: All Goblins are destroyed.

cards.name: Witch Hunter
cards.text:
{T}: Witch Hunter deals 1 damage to target player or planeswalker.
{1}{W}{W}, {T}: Return target creature an opponent controls to its owner's hand.
cards.originalText:
{T}: Witch Hunter does 1 damage to target player.
{1}{W}{W}, {T}: Return target creature opponent controls from play to owner's hand. Enchantments on target creature are destroyed.

cards.name: Dark Heart of the Wood
cards.text: Sacrifice a Forest: You gain 3 life.
cards.flavor: Even the Goblins shun this haunted place, where the tree limbs twist in agony and the ground seems to scuttle under your feet.
cards.originalText:
You may sacrifice a forest to gain 3 life.
Counts as both a black card and a green card.

cards.name: Marsh Goblins
cards.text: Swampwalk (This creature can't be blocked as long as defending player controls a Swamp.)
cards.flavor: Even the other Goblin races shun the Marsh Goblins, thanks to certain unwholesome customs they practice.
cards.originalText:
Swampwalk
Counts as both a black card and a red card.

cards.name: Scarwood Goblins
cards.flavor: Larger and more cunning than most Goblins, Scarwood Goblins are thankfully found only in isolated pockets.
cards.originalText: Counts as both a green card and a red card.

cards.name: City of Shadows
cards.text:
{T}, Exile a creature you control: Put a storage counter on City of Shadows.
{T}: Add {C} for each storage counter on City of Shadows.

rulings.text: The storage counters aren't removed when you activate the mana ability.

You can activate City of Shadows's second ability while it has no storage counters on it, though it won't add any mana to your mana pool in this case. You did not tap it for mana, though, in case any abilities (such as the ability of a Fertile Ground enchanting it) care about that.

cards.originalText:
{T}: Sacrifice one of your creatures, but remove it from the game instead of placing it in your graveyard. Put a counter on City of Shadows. 
{T}: Add X colorless mana to your mana pool, where X is the number of counters on City of Shadows.

cards.name: Maze of Ith
cards.text: {T}: Untap target attacking creature. Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to and dealt by that creature this turn.

rulings.text: Maze of Ith can target an untapped attacking creature. It will still prevent damage in that case.
The creature isn't removed from combat; it just has its damage prevented. It's still an attacking creature until the combat phase is complete.

You can activate Maze of Ith's ability targeting an attacking creature you control during the combat damage step or the end of combat step. It'll be untapped and the damage it had already dealt won't be undone.

cards.originalText: {T}: Target attacking creature becomes untapped. This creature neither deals nor receives damage as a result of combat.

cards.name: Safe Haven
cards.text:
{2}, {T}: Exile target creature you control.
At the beginning of your upkeep, you may sacrifice Safe Haven. If you do, return each card exiled with Safe Haven to the battlefield under its owner's control.

rulings.text: When creatures return to the battlefield, they are put onto the battlefield as if just cast. Creatures with X in the mana cost are treated as X is zero. Creatures which can pay costs when put onto the battlefield to determine abilities must have those costs paid at this time.
Token creatures cease to exist when they leave the battlefield, so this effect just exiles them with no chance to bring them back like you can with cards.
If changed to another land type, the creature cards are not lost but can't be released until the land reverts to normal.
When the creature leaves the battlefield any damage or "will be destroyed at some future time" effects are removed from the creature.
Auras on creatures are put into the graveyard and counters on creatures are removed when the creatures are sent to the Haven.
Creatures return to the control of their owners, regardless of who controls the Haven when it is sacrificed.
All cards in the Haven stay there even if they cease to be creatures. When the Haven is sacrificed, the cards come back onto the battlefield whether or not they are creatures.
Creatures return to the battlefield simultaneously.

cards.originalText:
{2}, {T}: Remove target creature you control from game. This ability is played as an interrupt.
During your upkeep, sacrifice Safe Haven to return all creatures it has removed from game directly into play. Treat this as if they were just summoned.

cards.name: Sorrow's Path
cards.text:
{T}: Choose two target blocking creatures an opponent controls. If each of those creatures could block all creatures that the other is blocking, remove both of them from combat. Each one then blocks all creatures the other was blocking.
Whenever Sorrow's Path becomes tapped, it deals 2 damage to you and each creature you control.

rulings.text: This has two abilities. The second ability triggers any time it becomes tapped, whether to pay for its ability or not.

The first ability can target any two blocking creatures a single opponent controls. Whether those creatures could block all creatures the other is blocking isn't determined until the ability resolves.

A "blocking creature" is one that has been declared as a blocker this combat, or one that was put onto the battlefield blocking this combat. Unless that creature leaves combat, it continues to be a blocking creature through the end of combat step, even if the creature or creatures that it was blocking are no longer on the battlefield or have otherwise left combat by then.

When Sorrow's Path's first ability is activated, its second ability triggers and goes on the stack on top of the first ability. The second ability resolves first, and may cause some of the attacking creatures to be dealt lethal damage.

When determining whether a creature could block all creatures the other is blocking, take into account evasion abilities (like flying), protection abilities, and other blocking restrictions, as well as abilities that allow a creature to block multiple creatures or block as though a certain condition were true. Take into account whether those creatures are tapped, but not whether they have costs to block (since those apply only as blockers are declared).

When the first ability resolves, if all the creatures that one of the targeted creatures was blocking have left combat, then the other targeted creature is considered to be able to block all creatures the first creature is blocking. If the ability has its full effect, the second creature will be removed from combat but not returned to combat; it doesn't block anything.

Abilities that trigger whenever one of the targeted creatures blocks will trigger when the first ability resolves, because those creatures will change from not blocking (since they're removed from combat) to blocking. It doesn't matter if those abilities triggered when those creatures blocked the first time. Abilities that trigger whenever one of the attacking creatures becomes blocked will not trigger again, because they never stopped being blocked creatures. Abilities that trigger whenever a creature blocks one of the attacking creatures will trigger again, though; those kinds of abilities trigger once for each creature that blocks.

cards.originalText: {T}: Exchange two of opponent's blocking creatures. This exchange may not cause an illegal block. Sorrow's Path does 2 damage to you and 2 damage to each creature you control whenever it is tapped.

cards.name: Abyssal Specter
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever Abyssal Specter deals damage to a player, that player discards a card.
cards.flavor:
"Mystic shadow, bending near me, /
Who art thou? / Whence come ye?"
—Stephen Crane,
"Mystic shadow, bending near me"
cards.originalText:
Flying
If Abyssal Specter damages any player, he or she chooses and discards a card.

cards.name: Act of Treason
cards.text: Gain control of target creature until end of turn. Untap that creature. It gains haste until end of turn. (It can attack and {T} this turn.)
cards.flavor:
"Rage courses in every heart, yearning to betray its rational prison."
—Sarkhan Vol

rulings.text: Act of Treason can target any creature, even one that's untapped or one you already control.
Gaining control of a creature doesn't cause you to gain control of any Auras or Equipment attached to it.
If you control a legendary creature and gain control of another legendary creature with the same name, you'll choose one to remain on the battlefield and put the other into its owner's graveyard.

cards.originalText: Gain control of target creature until end of turn. Untap that creature. It gains haste until end of turn. (It can attack and {T} this turn.)

cards.name: Air Elemental
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor:
"The East Wind, an interloper in the dominions of Westerly Weather, is an impassive-faced tyrant with a sharp poniard held behind his back for a treacherous stab."
—Joseph Conrad, The Mirror of the Sea
cards.originalText: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Ascendant Evincar
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Other black creatures get +1/+1.
Nonblack creatures get -1/-1.
cards.flavor: His soul snared by an angel's curse, Crovax twisted heroism into its purest shadow.

rulings.text: If Ascendant Evincar stops being black, it gives itself -1/-1.

foreignNames.name: 隆盛なるエヴィンカー

cards.originalText:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Other black creatures get +1/+1. 
Nonblack creatures get -1/-1.

cards.name: Banefire
cards.text:
Banefire deals X damage to target creature or player.
If X is 5 or more, Banefire can't be countered by spells or abilities and the damage can't be prevented.
cards.flavor: For Sarkhan Vol, the dragon is the purest expression of life's savage splendor.

rulings.text: Banefire checks the number you chose for X, not the amount of mana you actually spent.

Banefire can be targeted by spells that try to counter it (such as Countersquall) regardless of what the value of X is. If X is 5 or more, those spells will still resolve, but the part of their effect that would counter Banefire won't do anything. Any other effects those spells have will work as normal.
Banefire's ability won't prevent it from being countered by the game rules if its target has become an illegal target.

cards.originalText:
Banefire deals X damage to target creature or player.
If X is 5 or more, Banefire can't be countered by spells or abilities and the damage can't be prevented.

cards.name: Blanchwood Armor
cards.text:
Enchant creature (Target a creature as you cast this. This card enters the battlefield attached to that creature.)
Enchanted creature gets +1/+1 for each Forest you control.
cards.flavor:
"Before armor, there was bark. Before blades, there were thorns."
—Molimo, maro-sorcerer
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature (Target a creature as you play this. This card comes into play attached to that creature.)
Enchanted creature gets +1/+1 for each Forest you control.

cards.name: Blaze
cards.text: Blaze deals X damage to target creature or player.
cards.originalText: Blaze deals X damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Bloodmark Mentor
cards.text: Red creatures you control have first strike.
cards.flavor: Boggarts divide the world into two categories: things you can eat, and things you have to chase down and pummel before you can eat.
cards.originalText: Red creatures you control have first strike.

cards.name: Boomerang
cards.text: Return target permanent to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: Early Jamuraan hunters devised a weapon that would return to its source. Tolarian Æthermancers developed a spell that skipped the weapon entirely.
cards.originalText: Return target permanent to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Cancel
cards.text: Counter target spell.
cards.originalText: Counter target spell.

cards.name: Cinder Pyromancer
cards.text:
{T}: Cinder Pyromancer deals 1 damage to target player.
Whenever you cast a red spell, you may untap Cinder Pyromancer.
cards.flavor: "If the whole world burns, I'll never grow cold."
cards.originalText:
{T}: Cinder Pyromancer deals 1 damage to target player.
Whenever you play a red spell, you may untap Cinder Pyromancer.

cards.name: Civic Wayfinder
cards.text: When Civic Wayfinder enters the battlefield, you may search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. If you do, shuffle your library.
cards.flavor: "These alleys are not safe. Come, I can guide you back to the market square."
cards.originalText: When Civic Wayfinder comes into play, you may search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. If you do, shuffle your library.

cards.name: Cloud Sprite
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Cloud Sprite can block only creatures with flying.
cards.flavor: The delicate sprites carry messages for Saprazzans, but they refuse to land in Mercadia City's filthy markets.
cards.originalText:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Cloud Sprite can block only creatures with flying.

cards.name: Coat of Arms
cards.text: Each creature gets +1/+1 for each other creature on the battlefield that shares at least one creature type with it. (For example, if two Goblin Warriors and a Goblin Shaman are on the battlefield, each gets +2/+2.)
cards.flavor:
"Hup, two, three, four,
Dunno how to count no more."

rulings.text: If a creature has more than one creature type, and one of those types matches the creature you are calculating for, then count that creature. Only one type needs to match in order to get counted.
If you have a creature with more than one creature type, count all creatures which have either creature type.
Sharing multiple creature types doesn't give an additional bonus. Coat of Arms counts creatures, not creature types.

cards.originalText: Each creature gets +1/+1 for each other creature in play that shares a creature type with it. (For example, if a Goblin Warrior, a Goblin Scout, and a Zombie Goblin are in play, each gets +2/+2.)

cards.name: Consume Spirit
cards.text:
Spend only black mana on X.
Consume Spirit deals X damage to target creature or player and you gain X life.
cards.flavor:
"Your blood, your marrow, your spirit—all are mine."
—Mayvar, minion of Geth

rulings.text: The amount of life you gain is equal to the number chosen for X, not the amount of damage Consume Spirit deals (in case some of it is prevented).
If the targeted creature or player is an illegal target by the time Consume Spirit would resolve, the entire spell is countered. You won't gain any life.

cards.originalText:
Spend only black mana on X.
Consume Spirit deals X damage to target creature or player and you gain X life.

cards.name: Counterbore
cards.text: Counter target spell. Search its controller's graveyard, hand, and library for all cards with the same name as that spell and exile them. Then that player shuffles his or her library.

rulings.text: Counterbore has no effect on cards on the battlefield that have the same name as the targeted spell.
The cards you're searching for must be found if they're in the graveyard, because that's a zone everyone can see. Finding those cards in the hand and library is optional, though.

In most cases, Counterbore will exile the targeted spell. Its first sentence counters the spell, which puts it into its owner's graveyard. Its second sentence then removes it from the graveyard. However, there are some exceptions to this, as listed below.

If the spell's controller isn't the same as its owner (due to Commandeer, for example), it won't be exiled. The spell is countered and put into its owner's graveyard. Then the spell's controller's graveyard, hand, and library are searched.

If the targeted spell can't be countered (it's Vexing Shusher, for example), that spell will remain on the stack. Counterbore will continue to resolve. You still get to search for and exile all other cards with that name.

cards.originalText: Counter target spell. Search its controller's graveyard, hand, and library for all cards with the same name as that spell and remove them from the game. Then that player shuffles his or her library.

cards.name: Crowd of Cinders
cards.text:
Fear (This creature can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or black creatures.)
Crowd of Cinders's power and toughness are each equal to the number of black permanents you control.
cards.flavor: They envy the life-giving heat so much that they tear it from those who still possess it.
cards.originalText:
Fear
Crowd of Cinders's power and toughness are each equal to the number of black permanents you control.

cards.name: Deluge
cards.text: Tap all creatures without flying.
cards.flavor:
"From the sea came all life, and to the sea it will return. The sooner the better."
—Emperor Aboshan
cards.originalText: Tap all creatures without flying.

cards.name: Demon's Horn
cards.text: Whenever a player casts a black spell, you may gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: Its curve mimics the twists of life and death.

rulings.text: The ability triggers whenever any player, not just you, casts a black spell.
If a player casts a black spell, Demon's Horn's ability triggers and is put on the stack on top of that spell. Demon's Horn's ability will resolve (causing you to gain 1 life) before the spell does.

cards.originalText: Whenever a player plays a black spell, you may gain 1 life.

cards.name: Denizen of the Deep
cards.text: When Denizen of the Deep enters the battlefield, return each other creature you control to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: According to merfolk legend, a denizen of the deep swallows the horizon at the end of each day, bringing on the cold blanket of night.
cards.originalText: When Denizen of the Deep comes into play, return each other creature you control to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Dragon's Claw
cards.text: Whenever a player casts a red spell, you may gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: Though no longer attached to the hand, it still holds its adversary in its grasp.

rulings.text: The ability triggers whenever any player, not just you, casts a red spell.
If a player casts a red spell, Dragon's Claw's ability triggers and is put on the stack on top of that spell. Dragon's Claw's ability will resolve (causing you to gain 1 life) before the spell does.

cards.originalText: Whenever a player plays a red spell, you may gain 1 life.

cards.name: Drove of Elves
cards.text:
Hexproof
Drove of Elves's power and toughness are each equal to the number of green permanents you control.
cards.flavor: "The light of beauty protects our journeys through darkness."
cards.originalText:
Drove of Elves's power and toughness are each equal to the number of green permanents you control.
Drove of Elves can't be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.

cards.name: Drudge Skeletons
cards.text: {B}: Regenerate Drudge Skeletons. (The next time this creature would be destroyed this turn, it isn't. Instead tap it, remove all damage from it, and remove it from combat.)
cards.flavor:
"The dead make good soldiers. They can't disobey orders, never surrender, and don't stop fighting when a random body part falls off."
—Nevinyrral, Necromancer's Handbook
cards.originalText: {B}: Regenerate Drudge Skeletons. (The next time this creature would be destroyed this turn, it isn't. Instead tap it, remove all damage from it, and remove it from combat.)

cards.name: Dusk Imp
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor: Imps are just intelligent enough to have an understanding of cruelty.
cards.originalText: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Duskdale Wurm
cards.text: Trample (This creature can deal excess combat damage to defending player or planeswalker while attacking.)
cards.originalText: Trample

cards.name: Earth Elemental
cards.flavor: Earth elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.

cards.name: Elven Riders
cards.text: Elven Riders can't be blocked except by Walls and/or creatures with flying.
cards.flavor: "Wirewood cannot hide great size. Only with speed and skill can we survive here."

rulings.text: Creatures with the Reach ability (such as Giant Spider) don't actually have Flying, so they can't block this.

cards.originalText: Elven Riders can't be blocked except by Walls and/or creatures with flying.

cards.name: Elvish Champion
cards.text: Other Elf creatures get +1/+1 and have forestwalk. (They can't be blocked as long as defending player controls a Forest.)
cards.flavor:
"For what are leaves but countless blades
To fight a countless foe on high."
—Elvish hymn

rulings.text: It affects Elves controlled by all players, not just yours.
This card is now an Elf but has been reworded so that it does not give itself the bonus.

foreignNames.name: エルフのチャンピオン

cards.originalText: Other Elf creatures get +1/+1 and have forestwalk. (They're unblockable as long as defending player controls a Forest.)

cards.name: Elvish Eulogist
cards.text: Sacrifice Elvish Eulogist: You gain 1 life for each Elf card in your graveyard.
cards.flavor: "No matter how adept our artistic skill, our effigies can never hope to capture the vibrant beauty of a living elf. Perhaps that is truly why we mourn."

rulings.text: By the time this ability resolves, Elvish Eulogist will most likely be in your graveyard, so it will be counted by its own ability.

cards.originalText: Sacrifice Elvish Eulogist: You gain 1 life for each Elf card in your graveyard.

cards.name: Elvish Promenade
cards.text: Create a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token for each Elf you control.
cards.flavor: The faultless and immaculate castes form the lower tiers of elvish society, with the exquisite caste above them. At the pinnacle is the perfect, a consummate blend of aristocrat and predator.
cards.originalText: Put a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token into play for each Elf you control.

cards.name: Elvish Visionary
cards.text: When Elvish Visionary enters the battlefield, draw a card.
cards.flavor: Before any major undertaking, a Cylian elf seeks the guidance of a visionary to learn the will of the gargantuan ancients.
cards.originalText: When Elvish Visionary enters the battlefield, draw a card.

cards.name: Elvish Warrior
cards.flavor: As graceful as a deer leaping a stream and as deadly as the wolf waiting in ambush on the other side, elvish warriors are the eyes of the forest as well as its unsheathed claws.

cards.name: Enrage
cards.text: Target creature gets +X/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "You wouldn't like me when I'm angry."
cards.originalText: Target creature gets +X/+0 until end of turn.

cards.name: Essence Drain
cards.text: Essence Drain deals 3 damage to target creature or player and you gain 3 life.
cards.flavor:
"The elves are right: Death inevitably leads to life. But the truly powerful don't just experience this cycle. They control it."
—Crovax, ascendant evincar

rulings.text: If the target creature or player is an illegal target when Essence Drain tries to resolve, it will be countered and none of its effects will happen. You won't gain 3 life.

cards.originalText: Essence Drain deals 3 damage to target creature or player and you gain 3 life.

cards.name: Essence Scatter
cards.text: Counter target creature spell.
cards.flavor: Some wizards compete not to summon the most interesting creatures, but to create the most interesting aftereffects when a summons goes awry.

rulings.text: A "creature spell" is any spell with the type creature, even if it has other types such as artifact or enchantment. Older cards of type summon are also creature spells.

cards.originalText: Counter target creature spell.

cards.name: Evacuation
cards.text: Return all creatures to their owners' hands.
cards.flavor:
"Once I supply the breeze, you'll see your warriors for the smoke they truly are."
—Alexi, zephyr mage
cards.originalText: Return all creatures to their owners' hands.

cards.name: Eyeblight's Ending
cards.text: Destroy target non-Elf creature.
cards.flavor:
"Those without beauty are Lorwyn's greatest tumor. The winnowers have an unpleasant duty, but a necessary one."
—Eidren, perfect of Lys Alana
cards.originalText: Destroy target non-Elf creature.

cards.name: Furnace of Rath
cards.text: If a source would deal damage to a creature or player, it deals double that damage to that creature or player instead.
cards.flavor: The furnace awaits the next master who would stoke the fires of apocalypse.

rulings.text: If a spell or ability damages multiple things, divide up the damage before applying this effect. This means you can't normally end up with an odd amount of damage on something.
The trample rules cause damage to be divided before it is doubled.
If you have two of these on the battlefield, the damage is multiplied by 4.
The multiplied damage counts in all ways as if it came from the original source. Furnace of Rath is not the source.

If multiple effects modify how damage will be dealt, the player who would be dealt damage or the controller of the creature that would be dealt damage chooses the order to apply the effects. For example, Mending Hands says, "Prevent the next 4 damage that would be dealt to target creature or player this turn." Suppose a spell would deal 5 damage to a player who has cast Mending Hands targeting himself or herself. That player can either (a) prevent 4 damage first and then let Furnace of Rath double the remaining 1 damage, taking 2 damage, or (b) double the damage to 10 and then prevent 4 damage, taking 6 damage.

cards.originalText: If a source would deal damage to a creature or player, it deals double that damage to that creature or player instead.

cards.name: Gaea's Herald
cards.text: Creature spells can't be countered.
cards.flavor: "Gaea sings with the voice of nature rampant: a thousand howls, chitters, and cries, and none of them can be ignored."

rulings.text: The ability applies to your opponent's spells as well as your own.

cards.originalText: Creature spells can't be countered.

cards.name: Giant Growth
cards.text: Target creature gets +3/+3 until end of turn.
cards.originalText: Target creature gets +3/+3 until end of turn.

cards.name: Giant Spider
cards.text: Reach (This creature can block creatures with flying.)
cards.flavor:
"When I trained under Multani, he bade me sit for hours watching Yavimaya's spiders. From them I learned stealth, patience, and the best way to snare a wind drake."
—Mirri of the Weatherlight

rulings.text: This card now uses the Reach keyword ability to enable the blocking of flying creatures. This works because a creature with flying can only be blocked by creatures with flying or reach.

cards.originalText: Reach (This creature can block creatures with flying.)

cards.name: Goblin Piker
cards.flavor: Once he'd worked out which end of the thing was sharp, he was promoted to guard duty.

cards.name: Goblin Sky Raider
cards.text: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
cards.flavor: The goblin word for "flying" is more accurately translated as "falling slowly."
cards.originalText: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Greenweaver Druid
cards.text: {T}: Add {G}{G} to your mana pool.
cards.flavor: The other tribes call them fanatics, but none deny that the Mul Daya elves have an iron-strong bond to some force greater than themselves.
cards.originalText: {T}: Add {G}{G} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Hill Giant
cards.flavor: Fortunately, hill giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.

cards.name: Howl of the Night Pack
cards.text: Create a 2/2 green Wolf creature token for each Forest you control.
cards.flavor: The murderous horrors of Raven's Run are legendary, but even that haunted place goes quiet when the night wolves howl.

rulings.text: The number of Wolves you put onto the battlefield is based on the number of Forests you control when Howl of the Night Pack resolves.
Howl of the Night Pack counts any land you control with the subtype Forest, not just ones named Forest.

cards.originalText: Put a 2/2 green Wolf creature token onto the battlefield for each Forest you control.

cards.name: Immaculate Magistrate
cards.text: {T}: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature for each Elf you control.
cards.flavor: Elves of the immaculate class weave flora into living creatures—sometimes to endorse an elite warrior, sometimes to create a breathing work of art.
cards.originalText: {T}: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature for each Elf you control.

cards.name: Imperious Perfect
cards.text:
Other Elf creatures you control get +1/+1.
{G}, {T}: Create a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token.
cards.flavor: In a culture of beauty, the most beautiful are worshipped as gods.
cards.originalText:
Other Elf creatures you control get +1/+1.
{G}, {T}: Put a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token into play.

cards.name: Incinerate
cards.text: Incinerate deals 3 damage to target creature or player. A creature dealt damage this way can't be regenerated this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Yes, I think 'toast' is an appropriate description."
—Jaya Ballard, task mage

rulings.text: Regeneration abilities that would affect that creature can still be activated; they just won't do anything. The creature can't be regenerated for any reason, even if an effect other than Incinerate would deal lethal damage to it or otherwise destroy it.

cards.originalText: Incinerate deals 3 damage to target creature or player. A creature dealt damage this way can't be regenerated this turn.

cards.name: Kamahl, Pit Fighter
cards.text:
Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)

cards.flavor: In times when freedom seems lost, great souls arise to reclaim it.

rulings.text: The Legend rule only applies to two legendary permanents with identical names. If the names are different, even if they depict the same character, the rule does not apply.

Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)

cards.name: Kraken's Eye
cards.text: Whenever a player casts a blue spell, you may gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: Bright as a mirror, dark as the sea.

rulings.text: The ability triggers whenever any player, not just you, casts a blue spell.
If a player casts a blue spell, Kraken's Eye's ability triggers and is put on the stack on top of that spell. Kraken's Eye's ability will resolve (causing you to gain 1 life) before the spell does.

cards.originalText: Whenever a player plays a blue spell, you may gain 1 life.

cards.name: Lightning Elemental
cards.text: Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)
cards.flavor:
"A flash of the lightning, a break of the wave,
He passes from life to his rest in the grave."
—William Knox, "Mortality"
cards.originalText: Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)

cards.name: Lys Alana Huntmaster
cards.text: Whenever you cast an Elf spell, you may create a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token.
cards.flavor: From the highest tiers of Dawn's Light Palace to the deepest shade of Wren's Run, the silver notes of the horn shimmer through the air, and all who hear it feel its pull.

rulings.text: Lys Alana Huntmaster's ability will resolve before the Elf spell that caused it to trigger.

Mestre de Caça de Lys Alana

cards.originalText: Whenever you play an Elf spell, you may put a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token into play.

cards.name: Mahamoti Djinn
cards.text: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
cards.flavor: Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.
cards.originalText: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Megrim
cards.text: Whenever an opponent discards a card, Megrim deals 2 damage to that player.
cards.flavor:
"Pain is both a tool and a craft. Like any tool, it must be sharpened. Like any craft, it must be practiced."
—Hooks, Cabal torturer
cards.originalText: Whenever an opponent discards a card, Megrim deals 2 damage to that player.
